text: ਕਚਹੁ ਕੰਚਨੁ ਭਇਅਉ ਸਬਦੁ ਗੁਰ ਸ੍ਰਵਣਹਿ ਸੁਣਿਓ ॥

translation.text: Glass is transformed into gold, listening to the Word of the Guru's Shabad.

transliteration.text: kachah kanchan bhaiau sabad gur sravanah suniō .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Nalh
author.description:
Poet Nalh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Nalh wrote sixteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru.

text: ਬਿਖੁ ਤੇ ਅੰਮ੍ਰਿਤੁ ਹੁਯਉ ਨਾਮੁ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਮੁਖਿ ਭਣਿਅਉ ॥

translation.text: Poison is transformed into ambrosial nectar, speaking the Name of the True Guru.

transliteration.text: bikh tē anmrit huyau nām satigur mukh bhaniau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Nalh
author.description:
Poet Nalh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Nalh wrote sixteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru.

text: ਲੋਹਉ ਹੋਯਉ ਲਾਲੁ ਨਦਰਿ ਸਤਿਗੁਰੁ ਜਦਿ ਧਾਰੈ ॥

translation.text: Iron is transformed into jewels, when the True Guru bestows His Glance of Grace.

transliteration.text: lōhau hōyau lāl nadar satigur jad dhārai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Nalh
author.description:
Poet Nalh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Nalh wrote sixteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru.

text: ਪਾਹਣ ਮਾਣਕ ਕਰੈ ਗਿਆਨੁ ਗੁਰ ਕਹਿਅਉ ਬੀਚਾਰੈ ॥

translation.text: Stones are transformed into emeralds, when the mortal chants and contemplates the spiritual wisdom of the Guru.

transliteration.text: pāhan mānak karai giān gur kahiau bīchārai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Nalh
author.description:
Poet Nalh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Nalh wrote sixteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru.

text: ਕਾਠਹੁ ਸ੍ਰੀਖੰਡ ਸਤਿਗੁਰਿ ਕੀਅਉ ਦੁਖ ਦਰਿਦ੍ਰ ਤਿਨ ਕੇ ਗਇਅ ॥

translation.text: The True Guru transforms ordinary wood into sandalwood, eradicating the pains of poverty.

transliteration.text: kāthah srīkhand satigur kīau dukh daridr tin kē gai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Nalh
author.description:
Poet Nalh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Nalh wrote sixteen hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru.

text: ਸਤਿਗੁਰੂ ਚਰਨ ਜਿਨ੍ਹ ਪਰਸਿਆ ਸੇ ਪਸੁ ਪਰੇਤ ਸੁਰਿ ਨਰ ਭਇਅ ॥੨॥੬॥

translation.text: Whoever touches the Feet of the True Guru, is transformed from a beast and a ghost into an angelic being. ||2||6||

transliteration.text: satigurū charan jinh parasiā sē pas parēt sur nar bhai .2.6.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood
